ol.li:
Create a network.
On the left panel, click Project Network Networks and then click Create Network on the right.
On the Create Network dialog box, enter a Network Name and click Next.
Enter a Subnet Name, a Network Address (for example, 10.0.0.0/24), and click Next.
Enter Allocation Pools (for example, 10.0.0.2,10.0.0.254), and click Create.To find the network ID, click the name of your network. You will need it to configure your tfvars file and run terraform commands.

Create a router.
On the left panel, click Project Network Routers and then click Create Router on the right.
On the Create Router dialog box, enter a router name and click Create Router.
To connect your router to the external network (Ext-Net), click Set Gateway in the Actions column of your router's row.
On the Set Gateway dialog box, from the External Network drop-down list, select Ext-Net and click Set Gateway.

Create an interface.
On the left panel, click Project Network Routers and then click the name of your router.
Click the Interfaces tab and then click Add Interface on the right.
On the Add Interface dialog box, select the Subnet you created when you have created your network and click Add Interface.

Confirm that your sandbox environment is configured correctly.
On the left panel, click Project Network Network Topology .
Ensure that your router is shown connected to your network and the external network.

Ensure that you have at least 16GB of RAM.
To view your current limits, click Project Compute Overview

stentry.b: To Download the Configuration File and Key Pair

ol.li: To download the sh configuration file, click Project Compute Access and Security .

Click the API Access tabs and then click Download OpenStack RC File on the right.The openrc.sh file contains information about the hosted service, including region, tenant, and other information required to create a cluster. This file is pre-configured for your sandbox environment.

Create a key pair.
Click Project Compute Access & Security Key Pairs and then click Create Key Pair on the right.
Enter a key pair name and click Create Key Pair.
If the key pair does not download automatically, click the link and save the pem file in a convenient location. The pem file contains the RSA private key that you will need to run Terraform commands and to ssh into your cluster. The location of the pem file is relative to the tfvars file in which it is specified. For convenience, you can place the two files into the same directory.

stentry.b: To Load Variables from Your openrc.sh File
stentry.p: Add the variables from the openrc.sh file that you have downloaded earlier to your terminal session.

ul.li:
On Linux or Mac OS X:
Navigate to the directory that contains the sh file and source the file, for example:source 12345678901234-Project-openrc.sh
When prompted, enter your OpenStack password.

On Windows:
Create a file named openrc.bat and add variables to it from the openrc.sh file. For more information and examples, see OpenStack Variables.
